field_reports.description:
New fires have erupted in southern California, the blazes - named Laguna, Sepulveda, Gibbel, Gilman and Border 2 - flared up on Thursday in the counties of Los Angeles, San Diego, Ventura and Riverside. Firefighters have made progress in bringing the 10,000-acre Hughes Fire in Los Angeles under control, containing it by 36% since it broke out on Wednesday.

Fires have devastated the US state over the last few weeks, with the Palisades and Eaton fires scorching a combined total of more than 37,000 acres and killing at least 28 people.

According to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection (Cal Fire):
•  The Border 2 fire in San Diego spans 4,250 acres. Evacuation orders are currently in place. It is 10% contained.
•  The Laguna blaze in Ventura covers 94 acres and 70% of it has been brought under control
•  The Sepulveda fire in Los Angeles spans 45 acres and is 60% contained. The Los Angeles Fire Department said they had stopped the blaze from spreading and evacuation orders had been lifted
•  The Gibbel fire erupted in Riverside County, covering 15 acres. Fire crews have managed to stop the fire from progressing. It is 50% contained.
•  A bush fire dubbed Gilman in San Diego covers two acres, but the blaze's progress has been stopped

Governor Gavin Newsom on Thursday announced a $2.5bn (£2bn) state-level aid package to deal with the fire damage.

Dry vegetation and strong winds elevated critical fire weather conditions across Southern California on Wednesday keeping the blaze-weary region on high alert as firefighters gained a foothold on several infernos and prepared for rain this weekend.

A new brush fire rapidly exploded on Wednesday near Castaic Lake, about 40 miles northwest of Los Angeles, forcing almost 20,000 residents to evacuate and another 15,000 were under evacuation warnings. The new fire, named the Hughes fire, started just before 11am local time and consumed more than 5,000 acres in a little more than two hours, according to Cal Fire.

Red flag warnings were in effect until Thursday night for parts of Los Angeles, Ventura and San Diego counties due to low humidity and an expected uptick in Santa Ana winds, according to the National Weather Service. Wind gusts up to 50 mph were forecast with isolated gusts of 75 mph predicted for mountainous areas.

In Los Angeles, firefighters increased containment of the Palisades and Eaton fires that destroyed more than 15,000 structures and killed at least 28 people. Officials have warned that weather conditions may cause the fires to spread or spark new blazes.

As authorities lifted evacuation orders and some residents returned to their homes, officials prepared for a much-needed bout of rain this weekend. Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass issued an executive order to hasten cleanup efforts and mitigate the impacts of possible "toxic runoff."

Firefighters in Southern California reported steady progress Wednesday in containing two significant wildfires near Los Angeles while also addressing smaller fires attributed to arson. Despite improved containment efforts, ongoing Santa Ana winds continued to pose a risk of flare-ups and new fire activity across the region.

The Palisades and Eaton fires have collectively burned approximately 40,000 acres since last week, causing widespread property damage and resulting in at least 25 fatalities. In addition, the Auto Fire, which started Monday evening in Ventura County, has further stretched firefighting resources. Efforts to contain these fires have been challenged by environmental factors, including dry conditions and limited water availability in some areas, such as fire hydrants running dry in parts of the Pacific Palisades neighborhood.

The fires have also raised concerns about the long-term impact on California’s water infrastructure. Drinking water supplies in the affected areas have been compromised, and recovery efforts will likely face challenges as the state continues to experience increasing climate-related pressures, including prolonged droughts and the heightened risk of wildfires.

Containment of the two largest fires is progressing, with the Palisades Fire at 19% containment and the Eaton Fire at 45%. However, ongoing dry and windy conditions in the region underline the continued need for vigilance as the risk of additional ignitions remains high.

The Palisades Fire ignited on Tuesday, January 7, morning in Pacific Palisades, a neighborhood east of Malibu, as a brush fire. By Sunday night, the blaze had expanded to over 23,713 acres, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection (Cal Fire). It was 14% contained, and Cal Fire reported that the fire likely damaged or destroyed 5,316 structures, including hundreds of homes. At least 24 people were killed, including some who perished trying to protect their homes from the flames.

A Los Angeles County fire official indicated that a significant number of injuries were linked to two fires, while a city official in Los Angeles described Tuesday night as “one of the most devastating and terrifying” experiences she had witnessed in her part of the city. The Eaton Fire broke out Tuesday night near a canyon in the vast national forest lands north of downtown Los Angeles. By Monday, it had grown to 14,117 acres and was 33% contained, with Cal Fire estimating that over 7,800 structures were likely damaged or destroyed.

The Hurst Fire began Tuesday night in Sylmar, a suburban neighborhood north of San Fernando, as a brush fire. By Saturday night, it had spread to 799 acres and was 95% contained, with Cal Fire reporting that two structures were likely damaged or destroyed.

While firefighters were combating the largest fires, additional blazes broke out on Wednesday and Friday in the Los Angeles area. Crews successfully halted their spread and contained the fires. As of Sunday evening, the Lidia, Archer, Woodley, Sunset, and Kenneth fires were all 100% contained and no longer active, according to Cal Fire. Together, these fires scorched 1,539 acres.

results.summary:
The Palisades Fire ignited on Tuesday, January 7, morning in Pacific Palisades, a neighborhood east of Malibu, as a brush fire. By Sunday night, the blaze had expanded to over 23,713 acres, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection (Cal Fire). It was 14% contained, and Cal Fire reported that the fire likely damaged or destroyed 5,316 structures, including hundreds of homes. At least 24 people were killed, including some who perished trying to protect their homes from the flames.

A Los Angeles County fire official indicated that a significant number of injuries were linked to two fires, while a city official in Los Angeles described Tuesday night as “one of the most devastating and terrifying” experiences she had witnessed in her part of the city. The Eaton Fire broke out Tuesday night near a canyon in the vast national forest lands north of downtown Los Angeles. By Monday, it had grown to 14,117 acres and was 33% contained, with Cal Fire estimating that over 7,800 structures were likely damaged or destroyed.

The Hurst Fire began Tuesday night in Sylmar, a suburban neighborhood north of San Fernando, as a brush fire. By Saturday night, it had spread to 799 acres and was 95% contained, with Cal Fire reporting that two structures were likely damaged or destroyed.

While firefighters were combating the largest fires, additional blazes broke out on Wednesday and Friday in the Los Angeles area. Crews successfully halted their spread and contained the fires. As of Sunday evening, the Lidia, Archer, Woodley, Sunset, and Kenneth fires were all 100% contained and no longer active, according to Cal Fire. Together, these fires scorched 1,539 acres.
results.name: USA: Fire - 01-2025 - California Fires

field_reports.description:
Evacuees returned Friday to begin cleanup efforts after two hurricanes caused widespread devastation across the Florida Peninsula. Hurricane Milton struck less than two weeks after Hurricane Helene, leaving a trail of destruction, flooding, and power outages.

Milton resulted in over a dozen fatalities, and hundreds of residents required rescue. At least one person died due to delayed emergency response. The storm's impact was felt across the state, with tornadoes in Southeast Florida and severe damage along the Southwest Coast, Tampa Bay, and the Atlantic Coast.

In Tampa, downed trees, snapped electric poles, and damaged homes left many traffic lights out. This contrasted with the effects of Hurricane Helene, which caused more fatalities in coastal areas but left inland regions largely intact.

Hospitals across Florida are struggling to reopen, with thousands of displaced patients and nursing home residents still in temporary shelters. In Pinellas County, only two hospitals were accepting patients as of Thursday, and trauma cases were being diverted to facilities outside the county. Rising floodwaters led to the evacuation of over 200 patients from HCA Florida Largo Hospital early Thursday.

Power restoration efforts are ongoing, with 2.4 million customers still without electricity. The Coast Guard reopened several commercial ports in Florida, Georgia, and South Carolina after safety assessments, while others in Florida remain closed.

Hurricane Milton slammed into Florida as a dangerous Category 3 storm at around 8pm on Wednesday night near Siesta Key, weakening to a Category 1 as it moved across the state and offshore on Thursday morning, according to the National Hurricane Center. The storm caused a deadly tornado outbreak in St. Lucie County, where four fatalities have been confirmed, with the state anticipating more casualties, according to Gov. Ron DeSantis. Milton dropped over 18 inches of rain in St. Petersburg, resulting in a 1-in-1000-year flood event, while wind gusts of 100 mph were recorded near Tampa. A record number of tornadoes caused widespread damage, and more than 11 million people are at risk of flash and river flooding. As of Thursday morning, over 3.4 million energy customers in Florida were without power, per poweroutage.us. The roof of Tropicana Field, intended to serve as a makeshift shelter for first responders, was torn off by the storm.

As of Wednesday, October 9, Hurricane Milton, a Category 5 storm, is in the eastern Gulf of Mexico, moving northeast at 14 mph (22 km/h). The storm is expected to accelerate as it continues northeast through tonight, with a turn to the east-northeast and east by Thursday and Friday. Milton is forecast to make landfall along Florida's west-central coast late tonight or early Thursday, before moving across the state and into the Atlantic Ocean by Thursday afternoon. With maximum sustained winds of 160 mph (260 km/h) and higher gusts, Milton's hurricane-force winds extend up to 30 miles (45 km) from the center, while tropical-storm-force winds stretch up to 125 miles (205 km). The central pressure is an intense 907 mb (26.78 inches). Experts warn that Milton could be one of the most destructive hurricanes on record for west-central Florida, with forecasts predicting more than a foot of rain and a 15-foot storm surge. This comes just two weeks after Hurricane Helene made landfall in Florida, compounding the state's challenges. Over 12 million people are currently under hurricane watches and warnings, and evacuation efforts are underway across the region.

results.summary: As of Wednesday, October 9, Hurricane Milton, a Category 5 storm, is in the eastern Gulf of Mexico, moving northeast at 14 mph (22 km/h). The storm is expected to accelerate as it continues northeast through tonight, with a turn to the east-northeast and east by Thursday and Friday. Milton is forecast to make landfall along Florida's west-central coast late tonight or early Thursday, before moving across the state and into the Atlantic Ocean by Thursday afternoon. With maximum sustained winds of 160 mph (260 km/h) and higher gusts, Milton's hurricane-force winds extend up to 30 miles (45 km) from the center, while tropical-storm-force winds stretch up to 125 miles (205 km). The central pressure is an intense 907 mb (26.78 inches). Experts warn that Milton could be one of the most destructive hurricanes on record for west-central Florida, with forecasts predicting more than a foot of rain and a 15-foot storm surge. This comes just two weeks after Hurricane Helene made landfall in Florida, compounding the state's challenges. Over 12 million people are currently under hurricane watches and warnings, and evacuation efforts are underway across the region.
results.name: USA: Cyclone - 10-2024 - Hurricane Milton

field_reports.description: Hurricane Helene left Florida, Georgia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee, and Virginia to battle with record storm surge, wind damage, and catastrophic flooding. Over 230 people were killed across the six states and millions of homes and businesses were left without power. Western North Carolina is still without running water with no indication of when it will be restored.

Hurricane Helene, is the strongest hurricane on record to strike the Big Bend Region of Florida, the deadliest for the United States since 2017, and the deadliest in the mainland US since 2005. has had a devastating impact across several states in the Southeast. The death toll has risen to over 200 people. Thousands more have sustained injuries, though exact numbers are still being verified as rescue operations continue.

Hurricane Helene, which left massive destruction along the Florida coast since making landfall Thursday, is now causing historic flooding, wide-ranging power outages, and other damage in an 800-mile northward part that's affecting the Carolinas, Tennessee, Georgia, and other states.

results.summary: Hurricane Helene, which left massive destruction along the Florida coast since making landfall Thursday, is now causing historic flooding, wide-ranging power outages, and other damage in an 800-mile northward part that's affecting the Carolinas, Tennessee, Georgia, and other states.
results.name: USA: Cyclone - 09-2024 - Hurricane Helene

field_reports.description:
Since the fires began, the American Red Cross and county government have provided more than 5,300 overnight shelter stays in 16 emergency shelters on Maui and Oahu. The Red Cross is working with the Hawaiian Emergency Management Agency (HIEMA) to move displaced residents to hotels rather than congregate shelters. This temporary solution will help residents feel more comfortable as more permanent plans are developed. Many people continue to search for missing loved ones while also facing the loss of their homes and all of their belongings. Early reports indicate the climate-driven fires destroyed as many as 2,200 structures, most of which were homes.

 

More than 300 trained Red Cross disaster workers from Maui, other Hawaiian Islands and all corners of the country are working 24/7 with partners to get help to people as quickly as possible. With the help of partners, Red Cross has provided more than 32,600 meals and snacks to people in need. Emergency shelters are serving as multi-purpose service centers where people can access hot meals, relief supplies, health, mental health and spiritual care services, support with finding loved ones and casework assistance.

 

Approximately 6,000 local residents have begun their Red Cross volunteer training since the fires began. Preliminary damage assessment process is days ahead of our normal timeline, a result of our partnership with Microsoft's AI for Good Research Lab that is using sophisticated AI models and satellite imagery to analyze the extent of the damage. Damage assessment information is vital as it’s used to make operational decisions such as where to focus our services. It’s also the first step in validating addresses for residents that may qualify for Red Cross financial assistance.

results.summary:

The Red Cross is working with the Hawaiian Emergency Management Agency (HIEMA) to move displaced residents to hotels rather than congregate shelters. This temporary solution will help residents feel more comfortable as more permanent plans are developed. Many people continue to search for missing loved ones while also facing the loss of their homes and all of their belongings. Early reports indicate the climate-driven fires destroyed as many as 2,200 structures, most of which were homes.

 

More than 300 trained Red Cross disaster workers from Maui, other Hawaiian Islands and all corners of the country are working 24/7 with partners to get help to people as quickly as possible. It’s also the first step in validating addresses for residents that may qualify for Red Cross financial assistance.
results.name: USA: Fire - 2023-08 - Hawaii Wildfires

field_reports.description: In early August 2023, a series of wildfires broke out in the U.S. state of Hawaii, predominantly on the island of Maui. They have been recorded as the the deadliest U.S. wildfires in recent history and have damaged or destroyed more than 2,200 structures in the historic town of Lahaina. Most of these were homes, and now thousands of residents are displaced. More than 220 trained American Red Cross disaster workers from Maui, other Hawaiian islands, and all corners of the country are helping now with more on their way. Disaster workers are also virtually helping people affected by the fires. When the fires began, the Red Cross responded immediately, opening shelters for those affected by this climate-driven crisis. The Red Cross keeps disaster supplies pre-positioned on the islands, which allowed volunteers on Maui to offer immediate help to evacuees. Today our teams are working alongside partners to provide people with a safe place to stay, food to eat and emotional support during this challenging time. In partnership with the county government, trained Red Cross disaster workers are supporting emergency shelters on the islands of Maui and Oahu. The shelter on Oahu is helping Maui residents and tourists that fled in search of safety from the fires. Since the fires began, the Red Cross and partners have provided more than 3,300 overnight shelter stays. First responders are still conducting search and rescue efforts, and officials report communities will not reopen until these efforts are completed. Some power has been restored, but more than 5,000 customers remain without electricity. Communications are difficult with most cell service down, and critical infrastructure has been destroyed. Officials indicate it could be weeks before these systems are restored.

results.summary: In early August 2023, a series of wildfires broke out in the U.S. state of Hawaii, predominantly on the island of Maui. They have been recorded as the the deadliest U.S. wildfires in recent history and have damaged or destroyed more than 2,200 structures in the historic town of Lahaina. Most of these were homes, and now thousands of residents are displaced. More than 220 trained American Red Cross disaster workers from Maui, other Hawaiian islands, and all corners of the country are helping now with more on their way. Disaster workers are also virtually helping people affected by the fires. When the fires began, the Red Cross responded immediately, opening shelters for those affected by this climate-driven crisis. The Red Cross keeps disaster supplies pre-positioned on the islands, which allowed volunteers on Maui to offer immediate help to evacuees. Today our teams are working alongside partners to provide people with a safe place to stay, food to eat and emotional support during this challenging time. In partnership with the county government, trained Red Cross disaster workers are supporting emergency shelters on the islands of Maui and Oahu. The shelter on Oahu is helping Maui residents and tourists that fled in search of safety from the fires. Since the fires began, the Red Cross and partners have provided more than 3,300 overnight shelter stays. First responders are still conducting search and rescue efforts, and officials report communities will not reopen until these efforts are completed. Some power has been restored, but more than 5,000 customers remain without electricity. Communications are difficult with most cell service down, and critical infrastructure has been destroyed. Officials indicate it could be weeks before these systems are restored.
results.name: USA: Fire - 2023-08 - Hawaii Wildfires

contacts.name: Susan Malandrino
contacts.title: Communications Lead, International and Service to the Armed Forces

field_reports.description:
Earlier this week, Typhoon Mawar heavily impacted the U.S. territory of Guam and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands with intense winds as strong as 140 mph, flooding rain and a life-threatening storm surge.

Initial reports indicate there is considerable damage in the region. Most of the island is without power, some areas, including the airport, are flooded, and drinking water systems are down, as well as communication towers. Landslides have occurred, and a number of structures are either heavily damaged or destroyed.

In preparation for this storm, American Red Cross staged relief items on the island, including water, shelf-stable meals, clean-up kits, tarps and hygiene supplies. An American Red Cross disaster leadership team is on Guam and as many as 200 trained Red Crossers and more emergency supplies will be deployed to the island as soon as travel permits. With the airport closed, it is challenging to move people and relief items to Guam at this time and we are working with disaster partners to get help to where it is needed as quickly as possible.

American Red Cross is working with officials to coordinate the relief response, supporting sheltering and feeding operations, damage assessment and distribution of relief supplies, as well as training residents to help with the response.

Guam is also home to several major U.S. military facilities which have also been affected by the typhoon. Reports indicate the military is working to restore essential services to the installations.

With more than 21,000 military members and their dependents on Guam, the American Red Cross is supporting the military Emergency Family Assistance Center (EFAC) — a central location where families can receive disaster relief services and information — on Andersen Air Force Base and Navy Base Guam.

results.summary: Super Typhoon Mawar which strengthened into a Category 5 on Tuesday, May 23 is expected to make landfall in Guam. The cyclone is recorded as one of the strongest hitting in Western Pacific region, with estimated winds up to 230 kmph (143mph). American Red Cross has a strong volunteer base in Guam and is actively mobilizing personnel and volunteers to address livelihoods needs by preparing emergency relief supplies, positioning additional personnel, and supporting preparedness activities in shelters. Immediately after landfall, the teams will begin damage assessments and mobilize additional personnel and relief supplies as needed.
results.name: USA: Cyclone - 2023-05 - Super Typhoon Mawar

field_reports.description: More than a week after Typhoon Mawar hit Guam, many residents are still without power and water and it could be weeks before these systems are fully restored on the western Pacific islands. The American Red Cross is helping people with medical or disability needs, as well as emotional and spiritual support during these challenging times. More than 180 trained Red Cross disaster workers from all over the United States are on the islands working closely with officials, partners and community, and humanitarian agencies; distributing relief supplies (clean-up kits, tarps, coolers, flashlights and personal hygiene supplies), supporting feeding efforts in community-run shelters, and assessing residential damage to help and support people affected by this powerful storm. The American Red Cross has served approximately 2,400 households so far and are working with village mayors to begin hosting community distribution sites for impacted residents to find relief supplies, recovery assistance and information. The American Red Cross is also supporting feeding in the community-run shelters and has provided as many as 26,000 meals and snacks since the storm hit the islands. The Red Cross is supporting the military Emergency Family Assistance Center (EFAC) on Andersen Air Force Base and Navy Base Guam where families can receive disaster relief services and information.

results.summary: More than a week after Typhoon Mawar hit Guam, many residents are still without power and water and it could be weeks before these systems are fully restored on the western Pacific islands. The American Red Cross is helping people with medical or disability needs, as well as emotional and spiritual support during these challenging times. More than 180 trained Red Cross disaster workers from all over the United States are on the islands working closely with officials, partners and community, and humanitarian agencies; distributing relief supplies (clean-up kits, tarps, coolers, flashlights and personal hygiene supplies), supporting feeding efforts in community-run shelters, and assessing residential damage to help and support people affected by this powerful storm. The American Red Cross has served approximately 2,400 households so far and are working with village mayors to begin hosting community distribution sites for impacted residents to find relief supplies, recovery assistance and information. The American Red Cross is also supporting feeding in the community-run shelters and has provided as many as 26,000 meals and snacks since the storm hit the islands. The Red Cross is supporting the military Emergency Family Assistance Center (EFAC) on Andersen Air Force Base and Navy Base Guam where families can receive disaster relief services and information.
results.name: USA: Cyclone - 2023-05 - Super Typhoon Mawar

contacts.name: Susan Malandrino
contacts.title: Communications Lead, International and Service to the Armed Forces

field_reports.description:
The Red Cross is preparing to respond in western Alaska where Typhoon Merbok struck over the weekend, causing flooding powerful enough to uproot buildings and forcing residents to seek shelter.

With winter’s freezing temperatures expected in the coming weeks, flooded homes and airport runways are a major concern. Air travel and delivery of goods and supplies by barge will halt soon because of the oncoming cold weather. In some remote areas, these are the main methods of getting supplies.

The Red Cross has disaster teams in Alaska ready to offer help and comfort to those affected by this massive storm as soon as it is safe to do so. Disaster workers from out of state arrived in Anchorage last week and more Red Cross teams are on their way to support this operation. Communities have been identified that need assistance and Red Cross teams are working with community leaders to provide help where it is needed most. In Alaska, shelters are run by the government and community groups and the Red Cross is preparing to support them if needed. The Red Cross will coordinate with officials and emergency management to help those affected.

contacts.name: Susan Malandrino
contacts.title: Communications Lead, International and Service to the Armed Forces

field_reports.description:
Hurricane Fiona hit Puerto Rico with 75 mph winds and heavy rain, knocking out power to the entire island. Some areas might see as much as 30 inches of rain before the storm moves away from Puerto Rico, and flooding, mudslides and debris are making it difficult to restore power and assess the damage. Hundreds have been evacuated and people are being urged to move to higher ground now. Rescuers have conducted multiple swift water rescues. Public transportation is at a halt and airports and seaports continue to remain closed

In Puerto Rico, the government opens and manages emergency shelters. Reports indicate more than 120 shelters are open, many in schools powered by solar micro-grid power systems installed with an American Red Cross contribution of nearly $1.5 million after Hurricane Maria devastated Puerto Rico in 2017.

Prior to Hurricane Fiona making landfall, the Red Cross prepositioned blood products to support hospitals in Puerto Rico. On Monday, the Red Cross sent additional units of platelets to support patients there. Platelets have a short shelf life of only 5 days. The Red Cross urges those in non-impacted areas to give blood and platelets by visiting RedCrossBlood.org.

Fiona also passed over the U.S. Virgin Islands with heavy rain and 45 mph winds. Many are without power and the main hospital and 911 Center are operating with generator power. Trained Red Cross disaster workers will help with damage assessment when it is safe and are working with officials to determine what help is needed. American Red Cross disaster teams are in Puerto Rico and nearby, poised to resume relief services when it is safe do so.

contacts.name: Jenelle Eli
contacts.title: Sr. Director, Media Relations + International Communications

field_reports.description:
As the remnants of Hurricane Ida made their way north, the damage left behind in Louisiana and Mississippi is becoming clearer. More than 1 million people remain without power and some areas may not have electricity for weeks even as temperatures continue to soar; homes and businesses are destroyed; cell phone, water and sewer services are down in many areas; roads are damaged or blocked; and many communities remain flooded. Evacuees have been asked to not return to their homes until it is safe to do so, in some areas water is chest high and snakes and alligators have been sighted. Many communities that are still recovering from the devastation of hurricanes Laura and Delta just a year ago are now facing flooded homes yet again along with another lengthy recovery effort. Experts point to climate change as being partially responsible for the rapid strengthening that Ida underwent before making landfall.

American Red Cross is focused on providing safe shelter, meals, and comfort for people in need for weeks and months to come. Tuesday night, more than 2,100 people sought refuge in 38 Red Cross and community shelters across Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and Texas. 580 trained Red Cross workers are on the ground now with hundreds more traveling from all over the country to help. With the help of partners, the Red Cross has already provided more than 17,000 meals and snacks and distributed 770 relief items. Mobile kitchens capable of preparing tens of thousands of meals are being set up with the help of the Southern Baptist Convention. In the coming days, dozens of Red Cross emergency response vehicles will be bringing additional food and relief supplies to people across the region.

contacts.name: Jenelle Eli
contacts.title: Sr. Director, Media Relations + International Communications

field_reports.description: Hurricane Ida made landfall in Louisiana as a Category 4 storm on August 29 and has inundated parts of the state with heavy rain and strong winds. The American Red Cross is helping those affected and urges everyone to follow storm safety steps. Elsa carries 155 mph winds and could drop as much as 20 inches of rain, causing flooding, downed trees, power outages and a storm surge along the Gulf Coast. The storm is expected to bring tropical storm conditions as far north as the mid-Atlantic states before heading out to sea Friday. The American Red Cross has deployed hundreds of trained disaster workers and relief supplies to shelter and support thousands of people in evacuation shelters from Texas to Florida.

contacts.name: Jenelle Eli
contacts.title: Sr. Director, Media Relations + International Communications

field_reports.description: Hurricane Ida is expected to make landfall on the Louisiana coast Sunday evening as a strong Category 3 hurricane with winds of 120 MPH, storm surge of 7 - 11 feet, and total rainfall accumulations of 8 to 16 inches with isolated maximum amounts of 20 inches are possible from southeast Louisiana to coastal Mississippi and Alabama through Monday morning. American Red Cross is mobilizing and moving a workforce of nearly 500 shelter workers and enough shelter supplies to open nearly 100 evacuation shelters from Texas to Alabama to support nearly 20,000 evacuees in the next 4 days. American Red Cross is also preparing dozens of Emergency Response Vehicles, damage assessment workers, and others for immediate deployment so that they're well positioned to help communities in the aftermath of landfall.

results.summary: From 26/08/2021 to 27/08/2021, a Tropical Storm (maximum wind speed of 185 km/h) IDA-21 was active in Atlantic. The cyclone affects these countries: United States (vulnerability Low). Estimated population affected by category 1 (120 km/h) wind speeds or higher is 1.539 million.
results.name: GDACS Orange: United States TC Tropical Storm (maximum wind speed of 185 km/h)

results.summary: On 7/29/2021 6:15:49 AM, an earthquake occurred in United States potentially affecting About 400 people within 100km. The earthquake had Magnitude 8.2M, Depth:46.66km.
results.name: GDACS Orange: United States EQ Magnitude 8.2M, Depth:46.66km

countries.society_name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Red Cross

countries.society_name: The Trinidad and Tobago Red Cross Society
countries.name: Trinidad and Tobago

results.summary: From 30/06/2021 to 01/07/2021, a Tropical Depression (maximum wind speed of 93 km/h) FIVE-21 was active in Atlantic. The cyclone affects these countries: Barbados, Trinidad and Tobago, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Martinique, Grenada, Dominica, Dominican Republic, Haiti, Cuba, United States, Jamaica (vulnerability High). results.summary:
Context:

Tropical storm Elsa is now off the Florida Keys this morning and will move near or over portions of the west coast of Florida later today through tonight. It is expected to make landfall along the north Florida Gulf coast. El Centro de Pronósticos del Instituto de Meteorología, reports that Tropical Storm Elsa is moving away from Cuban territory and does not represent a danger for Cuba. All provinces that were on alert are to return to normality and to continue monitoring weather reports.

 

IFRC actions:

·       IFRC has been following up on Elsa since 28-June when it was forecasted to reach the Caribbean

·       Closely coordinating with the NSs of Barbados, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, Grenada, Dominican Republic, Haiti, Jamaica and Cuba

·       A total of 6 information messages and 1 bulletin have been issued

·       1 JFT and multiple coordination meetings with the country cluster delegations in Port of Spain and Santo Domingo

·       Tropical Storm Monitoring Dashboard: https://go.ifrc.org/emergencies/5379#details

·       IFRC Disaster Managers (DMs) and Disaster Preparedness Coordinator attending daily meetings with the CDPG

·       The Regional Logistics Unit (RLU) has been closely monitoring and preparing for a possible response

·       Preparedness Dashboard https://go.ifrc.org/regions/1#additional-info

·       The Communications Team has been in contact with NSs, has shared key messages, press release templates and preparedness messages on social media

·       The Community engagement and accountability (CEA) team has been in contact with NSs, sharing and gathering Information. The CEA team also shared the Hurricane Preparedness CEA summary tools and follows up with NSs

·       IFRC will continue monitoring and following up with National Societies

 

Cuban Red Cross:

·       According to the information from the Forecasting Center of the Institute of Meteorology, Tropical Storm Elsa is moving away from the national territory and does not represent a danger for Cuba. Therefore, it was decided to return to normality in the provinces of Sancti Spíritus, Cienfuegos, Villa Clara, Matanzas, Mayabeque, Havana, Artemisa, Pinar del Rio and the Isla de la Juventud Special Municipality

·       The Ministry of Communications evaluated the damage to the communications system caused by tropical storm Elsa and so far no serious damage has been detected

·       No major damages have been reported in the country and the government is responding to the affectations

·       The NS volunteers and staff are on alert and assisting in the needs assessments

·       The governor of the province of Matanzas assured that in spite of the persistent rains of tropical storm Elsa, it did not cause significant damage in the territory. The abundance of rainfall, the overflowing of rivers and the runoff caused flooding in low-lying areas and forced the evacuation of hundreds of people, as happened in the La Marina neighbourhood in the provincial capital

·       In total, more than 2,000 people were evacuated in state-run centres in the province and some 20,000 people found protection in the homes of family and friends and will be receiving support from the government

·       More than 20 percent of the population was without electricity service, and by late morning the restitution of the service was advancing at an accelerated pace. The director of the Electricity Company said that some 42 areas were without electricity service, which affected some 84,000 customers. It has already been restored for 12,000. 95 percent of the service should be resolved this Tuesday

field_reports.description:
What was Hurricane Zeta has for the most part moved out to sea, but 1.4 million customers are still without power today from Louisiana north to Virginia. The American Red Cross is responding from Louisiana to the Carolinas while continuing to help thousands of people struggling to recover from Hurricanes Laura, Delta and Sally which devastated some of the same areas along the Gulf Coast.

Zeta is the fifth named storm to make landfall in Louisiana this year, preceded by Hurricane Laura, Hurricane Delta, Tropical Storm Cristobal and Tropical Storm Marco. It is the 27th named storm in what has been an extremely busy Atlantic hurricane season.

field_reports.summary: United States: Hurricane Delta - Early Warning
field_reports.description:
Hurricane Delta is quickly moving toward the Gulf Coast and threatening many of the same communities
where thousands of people are still in emergency lodgings after fleeing Hurricane Laura. The storm is expected to make landfall on the evening of October 9.

Delta is expected to produce a dangerous storm surge and close to a foot of rain, leading to significant flooding from east Texas into Louisiana, Arkansas and Mississippi. The storm will then move north into the Ohio Valley and up the East Coast.

field_reports.description: Hurricane Laura continues to weaken as it passes over land, but the threat is far from over. Hurricane Laura is bringing life-threatening and devastating damage to the Gulf Coast and areas far inland Through Friday, Laura will bring as much as 18 inches of rain to Louisiana, Mississippi and Arkansas, continuing north over the weekend with heavy rain all the way to the Mid-Atlantic region. Before making landfall, the Federal Emergency Management Agency had encouraged residents in the Lake Charles, Louisiana area to evacuate.

Hurricane Laura has strengthened into a powerful Category 4 storm and is forecast to make landfall in Louisiana and Texas on the evening of August 26. The Federal Emergency Management Agency has encouraged residents in the Lake Charles, Louisiana area to evacuate.  Laura is expected to bring a catastrophic storm surge of up to 30 feet of water which could travel as far as 30 miles from the coast, along with as many as 15 inches of rain and strong winds.

Hurricane Laura left terrible devastation in her wake in Louisiana and Texas. Hundreds of thousands of people are without power or water as the region copes with the compounding effects of heat advisories and the coronavirus pandemic. Many roads are still closed due to downed trees and power lines, making access into some of the hardest hit areas challenging. In Louisiana, many parishes still face evacuation orders and it could be months before power is restored. While the full extent of damage isn’t yet known, preliminary estimates indicate that thousands of homes could either be destroyed or have major damage across Louisiana and Texas.

field_reports.description:
Wildfires in California continue, with thousands of acres burned and many more under threat. The Red
Cross is there to ensure that those who need to evacuate have a safe place to stay. The largest fires include the LNU Lightning Complex fire, SCU Lightning Complex fire and the CZU August Complex fire, which have already consumed over 790,000 acres and destroyed nearly 1,200 structures in northern California. Two fires — the LNU Lightning Complex fire and the SCU Lightning Complex fire — are among California’s three largest wildfires in recorded history. The threat of new fires remains high as dry thunderstorms are forecast.
